author-notes.corresp: Muhammad Ilyas Sarwar, Department of Chemistry, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad 45320, Pakistan. Email: ilyassarwar@hotmail.com

abstract.p: A new dihydroxy monomer, 1-(2-hydroxypyridin-3-yl)-3-(2-(2-hydroxypyridin-3-yl)-1,3-dioxo-isoindoline-5-carbonyl)thiourea, with preformed trimellitic anhydride chloride-derived imide ring, pyridine and C=S moieties was synthesized. This compound was exploited to prepare three heteroaromatic poly(thiourea-imide-ester)s (PTIEs) by polycondensation with various diacid chlorides. Structural analysis of polymers was carried out by Fourier transformation infrared and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. PTIEs were readily soluble in polar solvents such as N,N-dimethylacetamide, dimethylformamide, dimethyl sulfoxide and N-methylpyrrolidone. Inherent viscosity and gel permeation chromatography measurements revealed high molar mass (140 × 102 to 101 × 102). One of the polymers showed crystalline behavior according to x-ray diffraction. Thermogravimetric analysis and differential scanning calorimetry were adopted for the thermal analysis of the polymers. Novel aromatic PTIEs possess high weight loss temperature (T 10) in the range 524–536°C and glass transition temperature of about 223–230°C.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polyesters are exceedingly versatile materials and have always been an attraction for the scientists. 1 The broad spectrum of the relevance of wholly aliphatic and aromatic polyesters, in medical and nonmedical areas, is closely connected to their fiber and film forming nature as well as biocompatibility and biodegradability. 2–4 However, their applications are limited owing to lack of some physical, mechanical, thermal and processing properties. 5 Therefore, it is important to investigate the thermal stability of aromatic polyesters with various functional groups introduced in their backbones. Polyimides, on the other hand, are a class of engineering plastics, which possess many outstanding characteristics including high thermal and chemical resistance, good tensile strength and modulus, low dielectric constant and ease of processing into films or coatings. As a result, polyimides have been extensively used in microelectronics (both in packaging and in integrated circuit fabrication). However, the commercial use of these polymers is often limited owing to their poor solubility and high softening or melting temperatures. To overcome these problems, much research efforts have been focused on the synthesis of soluble polyimides, in fully imidized form, without deterioration of their excellent properties. The introduction of ester, amide, ether or other flexible groups in the main chain of aromatic polyimides leads to enhanced solubility of these polymers, with a minimum sacrifice of their thermal stability. 6–12

Poly(ester-imide)s, containing both ester and imide functions, are hybrid structure of polyester and polyimides. The poly(ester-imide)s are, therefore, successful materials, which combines the advantages of high-temperature stability and processability. 13
,14 The majority of polymers have been prepared by the condensation of diacid monomers or their derivatives with hydroxy compounds. 15–17 New kind of heteroaromatic monomers are always focused and employed in the synthesis of advanced polyimide materials. 18
,19 In general, the heteroaromatic structure in the main chain of a polymer would impart certain properties to it. The pyridine with heteroaromatic structure generally has excellent stability derived from its molecular symmetry, aromaticity and polarizability resulting from nitrogen atom in pyridine ring. 20 Therefore, new kind of heteroaromatic monomers holding pyridine unit have vital contributions for the thermal stability, chemical stability and retention of mechanical property of the resulting polymer at elevated temperature. Consequently, recent research has been focused on the adoption of monomers containing pyridine nucleus structure to synthesize novel heteroaromatic polymers with good Thermal stability and processability. 21
,22

In this article, we reported a detailed investigation regarding the poly(thiourea-imide-ester)s (PTIEs) obtained from trimellitic anhydride chloride (TMAC)-derived imide ring, pyridine and thiourea-based diol and various diacid chlorides (terephthaloyl, isophthaloyl and adipoyl chloride). The synthetic procedure applied presented an unadorned opportunity for the inclusion of thiourea (C=S) functionality between imide and ester groups in the polymer backbone. Although, the inclusion of thiourea group as flexibilizing agent into poly(ester-imide)s backbone is a new and interesting research zone, thiourea group is known to impart features like biomedical activity, 23 corrosion inhibition, 24
,25 organic thermal stabilization 26 and semiconductivity. 27 In addition, thiourea along with its related molecules is significant as structural components in agricultural and pharmaceutical chemistry. 28 Thus, heteroaromatic dihydroxy monomer, 1-(2-hydroxypyridin-3-yl)-3-(2-(2-hydroxypyridin-3-yl)-1,3-dioxo-isoindoline-5-carbonyl)thiourea (HPDOICT), containing C=S moiety and pyridine unit has been designed, synthesized and exploited to prepare novel PTIEs with good thermal stability and processability. Synthesis of pyridine-based polymers has been very fascinating because of their unique and specific photophysical properties and their potential applications such as polymer-supported electrodes, photosensitizers, emission sensitizers, photogalvanic cells and metal ion sensing. 29 Pyridine containing heat-resistant aromatic polymers can also be investigated as new devices for solar energy conversion. 30 The dihydroxy unit in new polymers was designed in such a way that the synchronized effect of pyridine and thiourea moieties along with imide units capably enhanced their heat stability while preserving the processability. Actually, heteroaromatic pyridine and imide are thermally stable moieties, while thiourea group improve the solubility by developing weak interactions between the chains. To comprehend the relative influence of the introduced functionalities, we have explored solubility, crystallinity, molecular weight (Mw) and thermal properties of PTIEs. Investigation of results authenticated the approach of introducing heteroaromatic group for the improvement of thermal stability. Physical properties of the copolyesters were also influenced by the incorporation of aromatic/aliphatic units in the main chain. Briefly, new dihydroxy compound can result in high performance materials through careful selection of the backbone structure. Furthermore, our curiosity in polyesters with good retention of thermal properties for heavy industrial applications (including polyester conveyor belt, resist-high temperature conveyor roller) has led to the examination of PTIEs prepared from heteroaromatic HPDOICT.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: TMAC (98%), isophthaloyl chloride (IPC, 98%), terephthaloyl chloride (TPC, 99%), potassium thiocyanate (98%), dimethylformamide (DMF, 99%) and tetrahydrofuran (THF, 99.5%) were purchased from Fluka (Biocen GmbH, Duesseldorf, Germany). N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP, 99%), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 99%), m-cresol (99%), chloroform (99%), o-dichlorobenzene (99%) and benzene (99%) were provided by Merck (Nottingham, UK). Adipoyl chloride (AC, 98%), 3-amino-2-hydroxypyridine (99%) and N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc, 99%) obtained from Aldrich (St. Louis, Missouri, USA) were used as received.

sec.title: Measurements
sec.p: Infrared (IR) spectra of monomers and polymers were recorded using Excalibur Series FTIR Spectrometer (Model No. FTSW 300 MX manufactured by BIO-RAD). Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) scans were obtained at room temperature through BRUKER Spectrometer operating at 300.13 MHz for 1 H and at 75.47 MHz for 13 C NMR using DMSO-d6. Elemental analysis was carried out using a Perkin–Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. Inherent viscosity (η inh) was measured in THF at 30°C with an Ubbelohde viscometer using polymer solutions of 0.5 g dL−1 . The molar mass (Mw) was measured through gel permeation chromatography (GPC) with a refractive index (RI) detector using THF as an eluent. Thermal stability of the polymers was determined by METTLER TOLEDO TGA/SDTA 851e thermogravimetric analyzer by placing 1–5 mg of the sample in aluminum oxide crucible at a heating rate of 10°C min−1. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was performed by a METTLER TOLEDO DSC 822e differential scanning calorimeter taking 5–10 mg of samples encapsulated in aluminum pans and heated at a rate of 10°C min−1. X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using x-ray diffractometer (3040/60 X’pert PRO) using Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, 30 mA).

sec.title: Preparation of TMAI
sec.p: Potassium thiocyanate (10 g) was boiled in ethanol (100 mL) and poured into 500 mL of ethyl ether to form fine white powder. The solid was collected by filtration and washed with 300 mL of ethyl ether. The potassium isothiocyanate obtained was dried in vacuum at 110°C for 10 h. In a 250-mL two-necked round-bottomed flask TMAC (0.1 mol, 22.5 g), potassium isothiocyanate (0.1 mol, 9.8 g) and 100 mL of dry benzene were refluxed for 6 h at 110–120°C. Later, the mixture was filtered through Buckner funnel. Trimellitic anhydride isothiocyanate (TMAI) was removed by filtration, and excess benzene was evaporated in vacuum oven at 80°C. 31

sec.title: Synthesis of HPDOICT
sec.p:
TMAI (0.01 mol) was placed into a three-necked round-bottomed flask (250 mL) equipped with gas inlet tube, magnetic stirrer and thermometer, followed by the addition of 100 mL of dichloromethane with vigorous stirring. The reaction flask was cooled to 0°C; afterward 3-amino-2-hydroxypyridine (0.02 mol) was added with continuous stirring for 1 h under N2. 31
,32 The precipitate was washed with 1% HCl, distilled water and brine. Ultimately, solvent was removed by filtration and dried under vacuum at 70°C yielding the solid product with 95.5% yield.

Elemental analysis for C20H13N5O5S (HPDOICT): Calculated = % C 55.17, % H 3.01, % N 16.08; Found = % C 55.02, % H 2.94, % N 15.94. FTIR (KBr) of HPDOICT (Figure 1): 3435 cm−1 (O–H stretch), 3315 and 1599 cm−1 (secondary amine N–H stretch and bend), 3004 cm−1 (aromatic C–H stretch), 1786 and 1723 cm−1 (symmetric and asymmetric imide C=O stretch), 1672 cm−1 (amide C=O stretch), 1369 cm−1 (imide C–N stretch), 1099, 715 cm−1 (imide ring deformation), 1129 cm−1 (C=S stretch). 1 H NMR (300.13 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ ppm) presented in Figure 2: 5.03 (OH, s, 2H, Ha), 7.35 (d, 2H, Hb), 6.39 (t, 2H, Hc), 7.24 (d, 2H, Hd), 8.89 (s,1H, He), 8.21 (d, 1H, Hf), 8.30 (d, 1H, Hg), 10.02 (s, 1H, amide Hh), 9.21 (s, 1H, Hi). 13 C NMR (75.47 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ ppm) specified in Figure 3: 153.1 (C1), 130.4 (C2), 107.1 (C3), 119.5 ppm (C4), 141.8 (C5), imide ring carbonyl C=O 167.1 (C6), 132.9 (C7), 125.2 (C8), 137.4 (C9), 131.3 (C10), 127.2 (C11), 135.5 (C12), amide carbonyl C=O 169.1 (C13), thiocarbonyl C=S 177.6 (C14).

sec.title: Synthesis of PTIEs
sec.p: The monomer HPDOICT (0.01 mol) and o-dichlorobenzene (50 mL) were added into a 200-mL round-bottomed flask and heated (100°C) with stirring under N2. Corresponding diacid chloride (0.01 mol) dissolved in o-dichlorobenzene (20 mL) was added to the above mixture and heated at 150–160°C for 20 h. 14 The reaction mixture was filtered and the solution was slowly poured into methanol. The resultant precipitate was filtered, washed with methanol and dried at 100°C under vacuum. The solid residue was dissolved in hot chloroform, precipitated in methanol and dried again. Yields of the obtained polymers are specified in Table 1.

caption.p: ηinh, Mw, PDI and % yield of PTIEs.

fn.p: PTEIs: poly(thiourea-imide-ester)s; Mw: weight average molecular weight; Mn: Number average molecular weight; PDI: polydispersity index; ηinh: inherent viscosity.

sec.p: Spectral data of PTIEs corroborated the structures of synthesized polymers. FTIR in KBr (Figure 4): 3355–3395 cm−1 (N–H stretch), 1595–1599 cm−1 (N–H bend), 3001–3010 cm−1 (aromatic C–H stretch), 1782–1787 (symmetric imide C=O stretch) and 1724–1736 cm−1 (asymmetric imide C=O stretch), 1675–1678 cm−1 (amide C=O stretch), 1362–1369 cm−1 (imide C–N stretch), 1089–1099, 721–727 cm−1 (imide ring deformation), 1125–1129 cm−1 (C=S stretch), 2886 cm−1(aliphatic C–H stretch in PTIE 3). 1 H NMR (300.13 MHz, DMSO-d6) (Figure 5): PTIE 1 displayed doublets nearly 8.24–8.36 and singlet at 8.81 ppm for imide ring protons. The doublets about 7.26–7.37 and triplet at 6.32 ppm correspond to protons of pyridine ring in the polymer backbone. Chemical shifts assignable for N–Hs were observed around 9.21–9.98 ppm. Signals corresponding to protons of p-phenylene units appeared in the spectrum around 8.07–8.20 as well.

sec.title: Monomer and polymer synthesis
sec.p: Preparation of TMAC-derived imide ring, pyridine and thiourea-based diol HPDOICT was accomplished using TMAI (Figure 6). Structure of the monomer was characterized through FTIR and NMR analyses. In HPDOICT, the stretching vibration due to O–H appeared at 3435 cm−1 along with symmetric and asymmetric imide C=O around 1786 and 1723 cm−1 (Figure 1). Appearance of alcoholic proton (5.03 ppm), in 1H NMR spectrum, verified the formation of diol compound (Figure 2). Later, the diol was exploited as a condensation monomer for the fabrication of new heteroaromatic polymers. Thus, PTIEs with alternating thiourea-imide-ester sequence were tailored from pyridine and thiourea-based diol and different diacid chlorides (TPC, IPC and AC). The composition and structure of these polymers were also confirmed by spectroscopic methods. FTIR spectra of polymers (Figure 4) showed characteristic absorption bands at around 1782–1787 (imide carbonyl symmetric stretching) and 1724–1736 cm−1 (ester carbonyl and imide carbonyl asymmetric stretching). The band in the range of 1675–1678 cm−1 also appeared due to the amide carbonyl group. The absorption band at about 1362–1369 cm−1 was due to C–N stretching of imide rings and the absorption at 721–727 cm−1 was due to imide ring deformation. The band in the range of 1724–1736 cm−1 should represent two carbonyl peaks due to the imide carbonyl asymmetric stretching and ester carbonyl. However, the two carbonyl bands individually are so strong that the overall absorption was seen as a single strong band in this range. Figure 5 illustrates the structure of PTIE 1 investigated by 1 H NMR spectroscopy. Disappearance of singlet in spectrum indicated the conversion of diol monomer into the polymer. Spectrum also depicted doublets nearly 8.24–8.36 ppm and singlet at 8.81 ppm for imide ring protons. Similarly, chemical shifts about 6.32–7.37 ppm owing to pyridine ring protons corroborated the structure of new polymer. 1 H NMR of the polymer also showed shift for –NH– proton at 9.21–9.98 ppm. The series of heteroaromatic polymers, having high η inh (up to 1.66 dL g−1) and Mw (up to 140 × 102), were obtained in good yields (Table 1). The fine balance of properties (thermal stability versus solubility) showed that structural modification of polyesters with the introduction of imide and heteroaromatic linkages increased their heat stability and glass transition without affecting their solvent miscibility.

caption.p: Synthetic route to the monomer and PTIEs.

sec.title: Organosolubility
sec.p: As a general rule, high solubility is a desired prerequisite for polymer processability. All PTIEs were soluble in polar aprotic solvents such as DMAc, DMSO, DMF, NMP, THF and hot chloroform (Table 2). PTIE 3 was partially soluble in less efficient solvent m-cresol, however, PTIEs 1 and 2 were insoluble at room temperature or on heating. The solubility characteristic of the polymers is in the order of PTIE 3 > PTIE 2 > PTIE 1.

fn.p: PTEIs: poly(thiourea-imide-ester)s; NMP: N-methylpyrrolidone; DMAc: N,N-dimethylacetamide; DMF: dimethylformamide; DMSO: dimethyl sulfoxide; THF: tetrahydrofuran
aSolubility is indicated as follows: ++: soluble at room temperature; +h: soluble on heating; ±: partially soluble at room temperature/heating; –: insoluble.

sec.p: Comparing the solubilities of PTIEs 1 and 2, which differ only by the orientation of p- or m-phenylene structure in backbone, PTIE 1 was rapidly soluble at room temperature. Therefore, PTIE 1 with p-phenylene structure had somewhat slower solubility than PTIE 2. Alternatively, aromatic-aliphatic PTIE 3 was rapidly soluble at room temperature in comparison with wholly aromatic PTIEs. Overall good solubility of the polymers can be explained by the favorable effects of C=S and ester units in the polymer macrochain. Moreover, thiourea group in pyridine-based PTIEs created distance between the macromolecular chains preventing close packing and consequently the diffusion of solvents is facilitated. The results clearly mentioned that C=S group disturbed the inherent rigidity of imide-ring containing heteroaromatic backbone, thus, enhancing the processability. Novel PTIEs also exhibited superior organosolubility when compared with previously reported pyridine-based polymers. 18

sec.title: Viscosity and Mw measurement
sec.p:
Mw can be studied viscometrically, which increases with the increase in viscosity of the polymer solution. η inh of PTIEs was in the range of 1.31–1.66 dL g−1 (Table 1), thus revealed reasonably high Mw. From these results, it was observed that wholly aromatic PTIEs 1 and 2 displayed higher η inh relative to PTIE 3. PTIE 1 presented highest η inh at 1.66 dL g−1 owing to –HPDOICT–TPC structure with p-phenylene units rendering higher chain symmetry and packing efficiency. Similarly, PTIE 2 having m-oriented rigid structure showed fairly high η inh of 1.59 dL g−1. In contrast, η inh decreased with the incorporation of –(CH2)4– linkage in PTIE 3. Semiaromatic PTIE, therefore, has lowest η inh at 1.31 dL g−1 owing to the presence of flexible alkyl unit along the backbone. GPC measurement of PTIEs also supported these manipulations. The weight-average Mw and polydispersity index are presented in Table 1. The high reactivity was observed for HPDOICT monomer, as reflected in the Mw of PTIEs, which ranged from 140 × 102 to 101 × 102. Correspondingly, PTIE 1 with p-oriented rigid structure exhibited highest molar mass 140 × 102, while PTIE 3 having flexible linkage showed Mw of 101 × 102. In general, novel polymers exhibited higher molar mass values relative to other reported pyridine-based polymers. 18
,32

sec.title: Thermal analyses
sec.p:
Thermal behavior of the PTIEs was studied using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and DSC. Thermal stability (TGA) of PTIEs was evaluated in N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10°C min−1. For a better comparison between the results, thermal behavior data are tabulated in Table 3. The aromatic polymers did not show significant weight loss below 500°C; they began to decompose in the range of 511–517°C and decomposition temperature at 10% weight loss (T 10) stayed within the range 524–536°C (Figure 7). Thermograms of the polymers were almost similar with each other (two-step decomposition) with maximum decomposition temperature around 600°C. The first step, around 520°C, was due to the destruction of ester groups that were more sensitive to degradation. The second step, above 580°C, was due to the degradation of polymer chain itself (stable imide and pyridine backbone). Among the polymers synthesized, wholly aromatic PTIE 1 containing p-benzene rings presented highest values of T 0 at 517°C and T 10 at 536°C. PTIE 2, derived from the condensation of HPDOICT with IPC, also displayed high values in thermal property (T 0 and T 10). The desirable thermal stability of aromatic PTIEs was ascribed to the presence of phenylene- and pyridine-based rigid backbone structure. The presence of heat-resistant imide ring also caused an improved stability toward heat. On the contrary, the presence of flexible bonds decreased the thermal property of PTIE 3 (T 0 365°C and T 10 379°C). The char yield of aromatic PTIEs at 650°C was about 34–38%, signifying good thermal stability. Certainly, higher char yields of PTIEs 1 and 2 was due to the presence of heat-resistant heteroaromatic content. The reason for the overall good thermal stability of new polymers is probably due to the intermolecular hydrogen bonding induced by the phenylthiourea and ester groups, which increase the interchain interactions, thus forming a stable structure. The glass transition temperature (T g) studied by DSC scans (Figure 8) was in the range of 223–230°C. Depending on the structure of diacid chloride component, T g of PTIEs increased with increasing rigidity and symmetry of the polymer backbone. Generally, the incorporation of rigid unit (p-phenylene) along a polymer backbone inhibits the free rotation of the macromolecular chains and leads to enhanced T g. Conversely, flexible linkage along the main chain reduces the rigidity and T gs of the polymers. PTIE 1 containing p-aromatic, imide and pyridine content showed higher T g 230°C, which was attributed to the fact that these units inhibit the free rotation of polymer chains. As expected, PTIE 3 having flexible alkyl sequence (–HPDOICT–AC–) displayed relatively lower T g value (223°C) on account of enhanced molecular mobility. According to the acquired results, novel PTIEs established high thermal stability, which could be justified by the presence of interchain interaction and preformed imide and heterocyclic pyridine moieties, relative to reported poly(imide-ester)s. 14
,33 The enhanced decomposition temperature and T g perceptibly make the present polyesters attractive for high temperature processing.

caption.p: TGA curves of PTIEs at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 in N2.
DSC thermograms of PTIEs at a heating rate of 10°C min−1 in N2.

fn.p: PTEIs: poly(thiourea-imide-ester)s; Tg: glass transition temperature; T0: initial decomposition temperature; T10: temperature for 10% weight loss; Tmax: maximum decomposition temperature; Yc: char yield, weight of polymer remained.

sec.title: X-Ray diffraction
sec.p: Wide angle XRD patterns for the synthesized PTIEs were collected with 2θ ranging from 5° to 50° (Figure 9). Only PTIE 1, a rigid-rod aromatic polymer, showed crystalline peak around 23° due to the existence of rigid planar segments (p-phenylene) rendering a better packing of macromolecular backbone. However, no remarkable crystal diffraction was detected for PTIE 2 and 3. The amorphous nature of PTIE 3 may be credited to their flexible –CH2– structural units that reduced the chain–chain interactions, resulting in unfastened polymer chain packaging and aggregates. XRD results were also validated by thermal analysis, wherein PTIE 1 illustrated higher values of T g and thermal property in thermogram.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Novel heteroaromatic dihydroxy monomer, HPDOICT, containing C=S and imide structure was successfully synthesized and afterward exploited as a starting material for the fabrication of PTIEs. This article reports the effects of introducing thiourea and pyridine moieties on the physical properties of PTIEs. The synthetic route employed in this work (solution polycondensation) demonstrated considerable benefits regarding the development of high-performance polymers, as it is simple, convenient and economical. Thermal stability of PTIEs was dependent on the chemical structure of their backbone to a great extent. Thermal properties were maximum for rigid rod PTIE 1, whereas they were found to reduce with the introduction of aliphatic linkage in the semiaromatic PTIE. PTIE 1 having p-phenylene backbone was found to be partially crystalline, while PTIE 2 and 3 owned amorphous structure. Nice balance of properties (thermal stability versus solubility) was also observed in the polymers. The results established that incorporating thiourea unit remarkably enhanced the solubility of ensuing polymers while preserving their high thermal stability. The reason responsible for such stability of heteroaromatic PTIEs is expected to originate primarily from their chemical structure composed of building units generally known to be highly resistant to increased temperature, such as heteroaromatic moieties and imide rings. Imide-dihydroxy monomer also possessed fine aptitude for the fabrication of high Mw polymers. Consequently, the combination of pyridine, imide and thiourea units along the backbone rendered the current polymers soluble, thermally resistant with high molar mass. Hence, heteroaromatic dihydroxy monomer, HPDOICT, can be considered as candidate for the fabrication of high-performance polyester materials. The heat-resistant PTIEs are certainly able to exhibit potentially valuable characteristics having vast technical and economic implication in heavy industries.

fn.p: A Kausar expresses thanks to Higher Education Commission of Pakistan (HEC) for pecuniary support in this work under International Research Support Initiative Program (IRSIP) and Indigenous 5000 PhD Fellowship Scheme Batch-III (063-111354-Ps3-068).
